title: How to Make Artisan Bread

steps.headline: Prepare the dough by mixing together the flour and yeast in the large mixing bowl.
steps.description: Add the salt, and combine. Pour in the water, and stir together until the mixture forms a sticky dough.

steps.headline: Coat the inside of the medium-size mixing bowl with olive or canola oil.
steps.description: You want just a light coating of oil in the bowl. If the oil is pooling in the bottom of the bowl, you have too much. You can use cooking oil spray to get a light, even coat in the bowl.

steps.headline: Use a plastic scraper to move the artisan bread dough to the oil-coated bowl.
steps.description: Cover the bowl with plastic wrap or a tea towel.

steps.headline: Let the dough sit for up to 18 hours before you want to bake bread.
steps.description: Set the bowl on a countertop or table at room temperature. Place it in an area free of drafts. The dough should rest for a minimum of 12 hours. If you let it rest for 18 hours, you'll get the most flavorful artisan bread.

steps.headline: Sprinkle some flour on the countertop or other work surface after the dough has rested.
steps.description: Scrape the bread dough out of the bowl and onto the floured counter. Add just a bit of flour to the top of the artisan bread dough.

steps.headline: Fold the dough in half one way, then in half the other way.
steps.description: The dough will be very sticky at this point. Use the scraper to help you fold the bread.

steps.headline: Drape the plastic wrap or towel over the bread dough, and let it rest for about 15 minutes.
steps.description: You can also cover the dough with the inverted mixing bowl. Letting the dough rest for 15 minutes will make it easier to shape.

steps.headline: Shape the dough into a ball after the 15 minutes are complete.
steps.description: Don't worry too much about making the ball perfect in shape. It can be sloppy and jagged. The bread will straighten out once baked.

steps.headline: Move the dough to the silicone baking mat, and cover it with the inverted mixing bowl, plastic wrap, or towel.
steps.description: Let the dough rest for another 2 hours.

steps.headline: Heat the oven to 475 degrees Fahrenheit (246 degrees Celsius) at least 1 hour before you want to bake the bread.
steps.description: The oven needs to be hot when you set the dough in so that the bread will spring up and form a high loaf. Place the Dutch oven or casserole dish in the oven as it heats up, but remove it when you are ready to bake the artisan bread.

steps.headline: Lift up the silicone baking mat, and slide the dough from the mat into the Dutch oven or casserole dish.
steps.description: Place the lid back on the container, and put it in the oven.

steps.headline: Bake the bread for 30 minutes with the lid on.
steps.description: After 30 minutes, take off the lid and continue to bake the artisan bread for another 15 minutes until it is golden brown and has an internal temperature of 190 degrees Fahrenheit (87.78 degrees Celsius).

steps.headline: Cool the bread before slicing and eating.
steps.description: The loaf will weight about 24 ounces (680.39 g), and you should be able to get about 20 slices from it.

text: Prepare the dough by mixing together the flour and yeast in the large mixing bowl. Add the salt, and combine. Pour in the water, and stir together until the mixture forms a sticky dough. Coat the inside of the medium-size mixing bowl with olive or canola oil. You want just a light coating of oil in the bowl. If the oil is pooling in the bottom of the bowl, you have too much. You can use cooking oil spray to get a light, even coat in the bowl. Use a plastic scraper to move the artisan bread dough to the oil-coated bowl. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap or a tea towel. Let the dough sit for up to 18 hours before you want to bake bread. Set the bowl on a countertop or table at room temperature. Place it in an area free of drafts. The dough should rest for a minimum of 12 hours. If you let it rest for 18 hours, you'll get the most flavorful artisan bread. Sprinkle some flour on the countertop or other work surface after the dough has rested. Scrape the bread dough out of the bowl and onto the floured counter. Add just a bit of flour to the top of the artisan bread dough. Fold the dough in half one way, then in half the other way. The dough will be very sticky at this point. Use the scraper to help you fold the bread. Drape the plastic wrap or towel over the bread dough, and let it rest for about 15 minutes. You can also cover the dough with the inverted mixing bowl. Letting the dough rest for 15 minutes will make it easier to shape. Shape the dough into a ball after the 15 minutes are complete. Don't worry too much about making the ball perfect in shape. It can be sloppy and jagged. The bread will straighten out once baked. Move the dough to the silicone baking mat, and cover it with the inverted mixing bowl, plastic wrap, or towel. Let the dough rest for another 2 hours. Heat the oven to 475 degrees Fahrenheit (246 degrees Celsius) at least 1 hour before you want to bake the bread. The oven needs to be hot when you set the dough in so that the bread will spring up and form a high loaf. Place the Dutch oven or casserole dish in the oven as it heats up, but remove it when you are ready to bake the artisan bread. Lift up the silicone baking mat, and slide the dough from the mat into the Dutch oven or casserole dish. Place the lid back on the container, and put it in the oven. Bake the bread for 30 minutes with the lid on. After 30 minutes, take off the lid and continue to bake the artisan bread for another 15 minutes until it is golden brown and has an internal temperature of 190 degrees Fahrenheit (87.78 degrees Celsius). Cool the bread before slicing and eating. The loaf will weight about 24 ounces (680.39 g), and you should be able to get about 20 slices from it.
